identity.bio: Marcus Chen is a 28-year-old DevOps engineer who believes the best infrastructure is the kind nobody notices. Raised in Vancouver by parents who immigrated from Guangzhou, he grew up methodically solving problems — first model kits, later server configs. After watching his university's deployment process collapse under a 3am outage, he became obsessed with making systems resilient. He has strong opinions about YAML indentation and genuinely enjoys writing runbooks.

history.origin_story: Marcus watched his university's student portal crash during exam registration — taking down 40,000 students with it — because one person ran a migration script manually in prod. He spent the next week rebuilding the deployment process as a side project, purely because the chaos offended him. That project became his portfolio. He joined a Vancouver-based fintech after graduating, spent three years hardening their CI/CD infrastructure, and now consults independently with a specialty in zero-downtime deployments.
key_life_events: 2018: Fixed university's broken deployment process as a side project — became his portfolio
2020: Joined Vancouver fintech, rebuilt CI/CD infrastructure from scratch
2023: Led zero-downtime migration of 4M-user platform to Kubernetes
2025: Went independent, specializing in infrastructure audits and automation
history.family: Parents run a grocery import business in Richmond, BC. Older sister is a civil engineer.

hobbies: Building mechanical keyboards (owns 7, each tuned for a different use case)
Reading post-mortems from major outages — finds them more educational than any course
Urban cycling with a dedicated spreadsheet tracking routes and elevation

favorites.book: The Phoenix Project by Gene Kim
favorites.drink: Tie Guan Yin oolong, steeped exactly 3 minutes

aversions: Clicking through cloud consoles instead of using IaC
Shared staging environments with no isolation
Slack messages that just say 'prod is down'
interests.lifestyle: Early riser, reads incident reports over tea, codes in silence, ends the day with a written EOD summary

motivations.core_drive: Make infrastructure so reliable it's invisible — the best system is one that never pages you at 3am.
goals: Short-term: reduce mean time to recovery for every client by at least 40%
Short-term: document every manual process until nothing requires heroics
Long-term: write the definitive open-source runbook template library
Long-term: build a CI/CD consultancy focused on early-stage startups
fears: An outage caused by something he knew was a risk but didn't document
Infrastructure that only one person understands
Being the person who has to say 'we don't have a rollback'
values: Documentation is part of the job, not extra
Small blast radius, fast recovery over perfect prevention
